posts.name: Wendy
posts.cooked: Starting from scratch. Should I buy a PC, a KitBot from Andy Mark, and what else? How do you make it go?

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
You will need -

A piece of plywood or other thin flat strong material to hold your electronics

PDH

Roborio

Radio

120 AMP breaker

2 (preferably 4) motors (and motor controllers if not getting krakens)

CAN Wires

Red 6 AWG wire

12V battery

2 battery cables

12 gauge wire (red and black preferably bonded)

22 gauge wire (red and black preferably bonded)

2 CAT5 cable

2 (or 4 if you went with 4 motors) 40 amp breakers for the PHD

2 10amp fuses (should come with the PDH )

a 6 AMP lug crimp (like the ones on the battery wires andymark sells)

4 to 8 levernuts (or other method) to connector your CAN wires

Something to cut & strip wire

Electrical tape to cover up exposed contacts

Game controller/pad.

I would include an RSL as well but it’s not required.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Are you part of a team?  You need a serial number from National Instruments (NI) to install key parts of code.  A team mentor or coach should be able to help you get that.

Follow Zero-to-robot from WPILib for the electronics, software installs, and some very basic programming.

You could look at the 2024 Everybot docs for the robot.  This covers the Kitbot chassis and includes some extras if you have any interest.   There is also some starter code available.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
First off welcome!

Our team worked on a knowledge base that includes links to many of the resources out there for teams.

FRC Zero is a knowledge base for students, mentors, and parents of FIRST Robotics Competition teams. The goal of FRC Zero is to provide a single source of information for all things FIRST Robotics Competition. This includes information on the game,...

Edit: Was typing this as the person above me did as well. Sorry for the duplicate info!

Specifically from that list you will want to look at https://docs.wpilib.org/ for most of the information needed for the control system in general. There is a Zero to Robot guide meant for new teams

Welcome to the official documentation home for the FIRST ® Robotics Competition Control System and WPILib software packages. This page is the primary resource documenting the use of the FRC ® Contr...

FIRST also released guides about the KitBot as well

*/

link_counts.title: FIRST Robotics Competition Control System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
paulonis:

You need a serial number from National Instruments (NI) to install key parts of code.

You can run without the activation keys that are released with the kickoff kit in the greenish NI packet. To just get up and driving with driver station you can skip this step. It might call it a trial/evaluation mode but for what is being asked about there is no difference.

posts.name: Wendy
posts.cooked: We are registered as team 10233. We haven’t paid the $6,000 yet. Hoping for some grants to come in that I applied for. Was thinking we would try it. We have one student that loves to build and one that knows java. I have one mentor that knows how to work with metal and all that. I’ve helped teams with marketing and been to competitions, but I’d be heading up this team and I need to guide the kids. I will buy the stuff on that list and a computer and then show them the zero to robot website and see how we go!!!

posts.name: Sean Paxman I 9191
posts.cooked: If you’re registering as a rookie team, you’ll get all that stuff in the kit of parts and you don’t need to buy it

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Welcome!  You’re getting some good advice, but I’d also recommend getting in touch with some local teams who will be glad to support you.  You can find them yourself using The Blue Alliance or FRC Map , or you can share your geographical location here.

EDIT: It looks like you might be close to frc3719 , STEM Whalers .

link_counts.title: STEM Whalers - Team 3719 - The Blue Alliance

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
art3misfowel:

If you’re registering as a rookie team, you’ll get all that stuff in the kit of parts and you don’t need to buy it

bovlb:

I’d also recommend getting in touch with some local teams who will be glad to support you.

Spot-on advice above.  Combining the two recommendations might be even more helpful.  If you have plenty of money and you want spares for everything or you would like to build two robots, then buying everything now and getting duplicates in the rookie KoP is a fine plan.  However, if money is tight, but you want to learn before kickoff, one option could be reaching out to local-ish teams to see if they have some or all of the robot components that you could borrow for the fall.  You may have 4 active teams within a 15 mile radius.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: The downside here is they wouldn’t get it until kickoff. If they want to practice now, or anytime this fall they would need a chassis from somewhere. The other advice about borrowing a chassis or spare parts from another team seems like the quickest way forward. The downside of borrowing a bot is they don’t get any practice assembling it.

posts.name: Chris LaSalle
posts.cooked: Looks like you are in New London CT., correct? If so I am in New, Haven. If you need help just DM me.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
I think you meant to reply to @WilliamsFRC instead of me.

Team 10233 is called Williams FRC and they are located in New London, CT, USA according to what I could find online, TBA doesn’t have the info yet, but it was available elsewhere.

Hello! We have a robust program to support rookie teams in their first few seasons. We would be happy to help you out. You already got some good replies from others on the components and Kitbots/everybot, but we’d love to chat and provide some advice from a 25+ Year Veteran team. If you reach out to 233pink@gmail.com we’d love to help out!

posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked: Wendy, Team 1699 Robocats in Colchester would be very happy to help you get started with things.  We have shared some more details in a direct message. Best, The Robocats
